bestBHT.bht: Barabbas, a leader in an insurrection and guilty of murder, was a notable prisoner. Some believe he was a false messiah or a leader among the Zealots, while others see him as a thief and a robber. His name, which means the son of his father, alludes to his ruined state and identity as a child of the devil. Barabbas was infamous for his crimes and actions, making him a well-known figure among the people of that time.

Philip Schaff: A notable prisoner. A leader in an insurrection in which he had committed murder (Mark and Luke). John calls him ‘a robber.’ Probably one of the Zealots, of whom Josephus speaks. His crime was really political.

Barabbas, ‘Barabbas,’ i.e., ‘the son of his father;’ although other meanings have been discovered in it. Some minor authorities call him, ‘Jesus Barabbas,’ and many think he was a false Messiah; but this is a mere conjecture.
John Gill: This prisoner is called a 'notable' one; that is, a famous, or rather an infamous one.
He was a thief, and a robber, and had been guilty of sedition; had made, or joined with others in an insurrection, and had committed murder in it.
A father's child that was spoiled and ruined, and a child of his father the devil.

bhtAttempts.bht: The verse tells us about Barabbas, a notable prisoner, who had committed murder and was involved in an insurrection. Some sources suggest that Barabbas may have been a false messiah or a leader of the Zealots. He was infamous for his crimes and known as a thief and a robber. Barabbas, the son of his father, represents someone who is spoiled and ruined, ultimately being a child of the devil.

He was widely regarded as a thief and a robber. The name Barabbas itself is said to mean 'the son of his father,' suggesting a characterization of being spoiled and ruined, revealing his true identity as a child of the devil.
